 The Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia Emergency Drought Recovery Project Grant Summary Recipient: Government of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia Implementation Agencies: Ministry of Rural Development, Food Security Department through Regional and Woreda Governments. Amount and Term: IDA Grant of SDR 43.5 million (US$ 60 million equivalent) Objectives and Description: To enable Government to help affected families survive the emergency, retain productive assets, and develop sustainable livelihoods, and to contribute to the stabilization of the macroeconomy. The project will: (i) defend critical human development expenditure by Government during the next year from the pressures caused by the current crisis; (ii) maintain the availability of critical economic inputs (particularly those needed in rural areas) and support the economic recovery process; (iii) rehabilitate and create communal assets using community labour within the affected population, and (iv) provide income supplements, and protect private assets for the affected population. The main indicator of project impact would be reduced levels of forced out-migration of affected families from their homes. Benefits: (i) Food aid received from bilateral donors will be used more effectively to assist the families affected by the drought, due to the existence of timely and complementary cash inputs provided by the Bank, facilitating the return to 'normal' sustainable livelihoods; (ii) the macro-economy will remain stable, and Government will not have to divert resources from its normal, long run efforts to create sustainable long term I ivelihoods for the rural poor; and (iii) mechanisms will be tested which may eventually evolve into the tools for providing safety net support to vulnerable - Ethiopians under the SDPRP and will supplant ad hoc responses to crisis. Risks: (i) Management capacity at woreda level and below is the key constraint to reaching communities as planned. The project will use existing, simple, systems to reach out to communities and improve the impact of programs; and (ii) the dependence of rural communities in food insecure areas on food aid may be deepened. To minimize this risk, the project seeks to use the food aid more effectively to provide income, and create infrastructure, which will support regeneration of productive assets and strengthening of long term livelihoods.  I. THE DROUGHT OF 2002 AND 2003 Background, circumstances of the drought and recent developments 1. On December 7, 2002, the Prime Minister launched the Joint UN - Government Appeal to the international community for assistance in averting a humanitarian crisis brought on by a gradually deepening drought in the traditionally vulnerable areas of Ethiopia. The call went out following the recommendations of a joint Government/Donor mission which spent the month of November assessing the situation. The assessment confirmed concerns regarding the severe food insecurity suffered by an already large group of 11.3 million persons due to the effect of climatic irregularities during 2002 on the main agricultural harvests in the Center, Center-North and Center-East of the country. An additional 3 million people could also face extreme food insecurity if the short rains, due in February 2003, fail.. 2. The crisis has been building since the short (belg) rains of February and March 2002 failed in the North and Center of the country. This failure reduced cropped areas in drought prone parts of the country, and it made it difficult for farmers to prepare adequately for the main season, as draught animals were undernourished and soils too hard for the ploughs and tools available to smallholders. The situation was made worse by a prolonged dry spell of up to six weeks between the short rains and the main (meher) season, which affected 55 zones and special woredas (about 80 % of the country). This delay in the start of the main season had the following effects': (i) it disturbed land preparation routines; (ii) it delayed sowing dates; (iii) it reduced the sowing of heavier yielding, maize and sorghum crops in favor of short cycle crops such as teff, and pulses, normally planted later in the season; and (iv) it deterred fanners from investing in (higher risk) inputs to raise yields, such as fertilizer and improved seed. As a result, fertilizer use dropped 17 percent from the previous year, and use of improved seed dropped by 70 percent. Fertilizer use was further constrained by the higher than normal default on prior season loans -- where a bumper crop kept crop prices low and constrained loan repayment. 3. A subset of 31 zones and special woredas (about 44 percent of the country and some of the traditionally food surplus woredas) suffered from unevenly distributed and unseasonably light rains. This resulted in (i) the need to replant, reducing crop density; and (ii) reduced seed set and grain fill. These effects reduced grain yields by 20-30 percent in areas which are usually surplus, and which show up as planted and producing (registering as green on the satellite imagery). 4. Should the moisture irregularities and shortages continue during the next short (belg) season in February and March of 2003, an additional 3 million persons, currently on the margin of personal food self- sufficiency, will need immediate humanitarian attention. The Affected Areas and Populations 5. The areas most affected by the drought are Afar region, northern Somali region, eastern Oromiya region, the lowlands along the Rift valley in the Arsi and East Shewa lowlands, stretching south into Wolayita and the Sidamo lowlands, and further south to Arba Minch. Eastern and Southern Tigray and Eastern Amhara are also badly affected (see Map). Estimates of the affected population by region are provided in the Map at the end of this report. The effects are most marked in the livestock areas, where the lack of moisture has been most severe. According to the nutrilional surveys, the 'From the FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment Mission to Ethiopia - 30 December - 2002 -- p. 2. I
 coping possibilities for the population in these areas have been exhausted. Malnutrition and wastage rates are high. Survival is the issue. Nutritional surveys in some of the affected areas show that malnutrition is already in excess of a Global Acute Malnutrition (GAM) rate of 10 percent -- a critical level which usually triggers an emergency relief response. According to WHO/UNICEF standards, a GAM rate of above 10 percent is considered serious and above 20 percent as of crisis proportions. 6. The food security situation of pastoralists in northeastern parts of the country has exhibited particularly rapid deterioration. A nutrition survey conducted in Afar Region Zone 1 revealed a GAM rate of 32 percent in July 2002. In August 2002 another survey conducted in Zone 3 of Afar Region showed a GAM score of 18 percent. A joint Government/NGO survey in the lowlands of East and West Hararghe in September 2002 estimated a GAM rate of 15 percent. Similarly, Fik Zone of Somali Region (bordering lowland East Hararghe) demonstrated a GAM rate of 21 percent. Since then, conditions have slightly improved in some areas due to food aid distribution between August and November. 7. Other areas where malnutrition has reached unacceptable levels include the northeastern lowland escarpment bordering Afar Region and the lowlands of the Rift Valley. In East Tigray, nutrition surveys in September 2002 showed an 11 percent GAM. This is twice as high as 2001 (6 percent) and 2000 (5 percent) levels, and demonstrates a situation which has been worsening since early September. East in the lowland gorges of North Gonder, malnutrition rates have reached 18 percent GAM. Further south in South Wello (Amhara Region), a survey conducted in August 2002 showed GAM rates of 18 percent and 17 percent, respectively and 13 percent GAM rate in south of South Wello in Oromiya Zone. 8. The nutritional status in SNNPR was in the acceptable range during the first half of 2002 with values ranging from a GAM rate of 2 percent to 8 percent. However, following poor Belg production, a further survey in September showed that the situation was already deteriorating with an estimated 10 percent GAM in Badawacho and Soro districts (Hadiya Zone). 9. The ultimate response to hardship is migration in search of an improved livelihood. A UN/EUE report of November 2002 indicated that some 35,000 people migrated from drought affected areas in East and West Hararghe and Arssi, where food distribution had been delayed, to the highland, high potential Bale zone in search of new cultivable areas and moisture. Production Estimates and Food Requirements 10. Grain production has been affected by the factors noted above. Cereal and pulse production for the crop year 2002/03 has been forecast at 9.27 million tons (which includes a normal short season harvest of 350,000 tons in early calendar 2003). This harvest level is about 25 percent below last year's harvest, and 21 percent below the five year average. The overall area planted to grains was about 11.3 million ha, about the same levels as previous years. However, there was a shift out of long- cycle grains such as maize, sorghum and finger millet, and into shorter cycle crops such as teff and pulses -- due to the fears of a short season set off by the late arrival of the main season rains. The factors affecting yields have been noted above. These effects are more marked in the drought prone areas of the Center and Center-North and Center-East of the country (see Maps). 11. Coffee production in 2002/03, which contributes over 70% to total exports, is expected to be lower than the previous year, due the reduced rains at and after flowering, and biennial production patterns. Incentives for treatment and care of coffee have deteriorated over the past few years, with the drop in world coffee prices, which will also affect yields. The drop in coffee production will mean a reduction in cash available at the household level which could be critical for families in the coffee 2
 growing areas affected by drought, in West Hararghe and Harari. Chat production, does not seem to have been affected. Overall, families in affected areas have reduced cash incomes with which to cope with the drought. Livestock 12. The Ethiopian smallholder production systems rely heavily on a livestock as a source of food, cash and draught power. In highland farms, which represent most of the more densely inhabited parts of the country, production systems rely on both crops and livestock. In the lowland areas, there is an almost complete reliance on animal based systems. These pastoralist systems are located in the extensive grazing areas in the Eastern, Western and Southern Lowlands of the country. The boundary between mixed farming systems, and livestock based systems is shown in Map 1. 13. The pastoralist areas in the lowland areas of the North, the Center-North and Center- East and have been the hardest hit by the current drought. In the third and fourth quarters of 2002, reported losses of livestock in the pastoralist areas of Afar, in north Somali, and other lowland areas (in Amhara, Oromiya and SNNPR) prompted interventions from the Government, NGOs and international agencies. The assistance was designed partly to boost disease resistance of livestock, through provision of vaccines and drugs and partly to ameliorate water and forage shortages through negotiated access to better resources. At the same time, food aid programs for the affected communities were reinforced, supplementing programs established two years before when four consecutive years of BeIg rain failure had dramatically reduced livestock numbers and incomes. Agricultural Markets and Prices 14. The domestic grain markets in Ethiopia function through a network of small, traders who buy surpluses from small farmers and sell in the nearby markets at relatively small margins. These markets function in relative isolation. Margins between markets in grain surplus areas and those in deficit areas are high -- above the level one would expect in other countries in Africa. Small grain producers as well as small traders are not well informed about grain availability and prices. Larger grain movements from surplus to deficit areas are constrained by high transport costs due to poor road infrastructure, weak market information systems, costly bag-based grain logistical management, imperfect grading and standards, and a quasi monopoly in the transportation sector. 15. Grain prices in surplus producing regions have been severely depressed for almost two years, through mid-2002. These depressed prices were a function of higher than average harvests in two consecutive years in the absence of effective price stabilization measures at the national level. In response, some of the donor agencies and Government purchased part of the grain for food assistance from the local markets instead of importing it. In 2001 and 2002 about 160 000 tons of grain each year were locally purchased by international agencies and distributed as food aid. 16. The grain market prices began to increase sharply during the latter half of 2002 when it became apparent that cereal production would be substantially lower for both Belg and Meher crops. Between October 2001 and October 2002, the nominal average price of maize increased by 85 percent, wheat 50 percent, barley 32 percent, and sorghum 25 percent. I. THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE The Framework for Addressing Vulnerability Vulnerability to Climate Shock in Ethiopia 20. The SDPRP indicates that 45 percent of the population lives on consumption levels that are below the poverty line. It is important to note however, that there are between 3 and 6 million people in Ethiopia who suffer from chronic food insecurity, and are at risk of starvation every year. The number of people who are chronically food insecure appears to be increasing. It is likely that most of these people live in the "drought prone" woredas (districts) identified by the Government. However, according to the Poverty Profile (2000), substantial numbers of chronically food insecure households do live even in the food secure woredas, requiring a nation-wide approach to the chronic food insecurity problem in the medium term. Studies indicate that vulnerability to clinmatic shock is cumulative. Recovery from any given event is slow, and often not complete, as the family may have had to sell animals and other assets in order to survive -- assets which are hard to r ecuperate in light of the very low consumption and savings levels such families face even in good years. A recent study of destitution in the three regions of North Wello, South Wello and Wag H-amra defined destitution as "a state of extreme poverty that results from the pursuit of 'unsustainable livelihoods', meaning that a series of livelihood shocks and/or negative trends or processes erodes the asset base of already poor and vulnerable households until they are no longer able to meet their minimum subsistence needs. They lack access to the key productive assets needed to escape from poverty, and they be-come dependent on public and/or private transfers."4 3 As reported in the paper on "Partnership for Accelerated and Sustainable Development and Poverty Reduction" presented to the Consultative Group in December, 2002.  21. A drought such as the one underway will require assistance to prevent precipitous shortfalls in the food consumption of the chronically food insecure households in the affected woredas. In addition, it will also drive the marginally poor families (who would otherwise have improved their position in a normal year) to consume their assets in order to maintain current consumption levels, thus eroding their already limited ability to cope with future weather shocks. Therefore, the appropriate government response to the current crisis should not only seek to redress the chronic food insecurity of extremely poor households in the food insecure woredas, but also reach out to the other marginal poor families elsewhere in the country so as to retain their assets and sustain livelihoods. The Policy Framework 22. Devastating recurrent droughts have been and will be the major development challenges of Ethiopia. Development strategies and policies of the country are geared towards alleviating the socio- economic impact of drought, ensuring food security and creating sustainable livelihoods for the poor. The government has been taking a number of basic measures to effectively address the problems of poverty and famine in the medium and long-term through multi-faceted and coordinated efforts. In this regard the basic framework is provided by Ethiopia's poverty reduction strategy paper, the Sustainable Development and Poverty Reduction Program (SDPRP), which includes the Agricultural Development Led Industrialization (ADLI) strategy, the National Policy on Disaster Prevention and Management (NPDPM) and the National Food Security Strategy. 23. The SDPRP was issued in July 2002 and indicates that about 45 percent of the population falls below the poverty line. The program calls for growth rates of at least 7 percent per annum over the next 5 years to reduce poverty rate by 10 percent. The SDPRP is built on four pillars: (i) Agricultural Development-led Industrialization (ADLI) and food security which recognizes firstly that market based agriculture is the engine of growth supplying domestic and international markets. It notes secondly that agriculture will require increasing technical progress, output diversification, and greater market interaction. Thirdly, industry and services need to grow in conjunction with the expansion of agriculture. Finally, there is a need for the development of a comprehensive food security and safety net strategy. (ii) Governance, Decentralization, and Empowerment through increased participation and consultation of the public in policy-making by decentralizing decision making authority; and empowering woredas (districts) as the center of socio-economic development; (iii) Reform of the Justice System and the Civil Service and (iv) Capacity Building for the public and private sector, including farmers, to support ADLI, reform of the judiciary and civil service, and decentralization and empowerment. 24. The Policy on Disaster Prevention and Management (PDPM) was issued in 1993 as part of the government's efforts to address the root causes of the prevailing vulnerabilities to drought and famine. PDPM discourages free hand-outs of relief supplies to able bodied people. The underlying principles and objectives of PDPM include: (i) no human life shall perish for want of food in time of disaster, (ii) the quality of life in the affected areas shall be protected from deterioration on account of disaster and the adverse impact is mitigated on a timely manner, (iii) the assets and economic fabric of the affected areas shall be preserved and best use of the natural resources of the areas shall be promoted to enable speedy post disaster recovery, and (iv) provision of relief shall not hurt human dignity, reinforce the capabilities of the affected areas and contribute to growth and development. In addition to tackling the issue of dependency for relief assistance, this policy seeks to integrate relief resources with development initiatives. A general guideline to this effect was issued in 1995 (which precedes decentralization). 6
 25. Under PDPM the preconditions for a disaster declaration are defined, and guidance is provided on the declaration of disasters, and on how to manage the response. In addition, under the policy, an early warning system and a relief response logistical system is put in place to respond to a crisis. Under its mechanisms for responding to crisis, the PDPM lays emphasis on measures such as Employment Generation Schemes (EGS) which are to be planned in advance, to provide employment to able-bodied disaster victims. This approach seeks to generate effective resource utilization and reduce relief dependence by (a) providing a means of income (in cash or in kind) to the most affected people in disaster-affected areas, (b) building up the assets of affected areas in order to improve their resilience to disaster, (c) creating conditions for eliminating the root causes of disasters and build up the infrastructure for future development, and (d) reinforcing work ethics of the affected population. Gratuitous Relief is provided to affected persons such as the aged, the very young, pregnant and lactating women, who cannot participate in EGS activities due to physical limitations. It is restricted to rural areas. There is no relief operation by DPPC for urban areas. In addition the P'DPM provides for the management of a National Early Warning System, relief related warehousing services, the establishment of a National Food Security Reserve, a National Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Fund, a transport fleet for coverage where commercial fleets refuse to go, and measures for donor coordination. 26. In the context of the ongoing decentralization, improving the management and implementation capacity at all levels will be critical. For one thing, the Government has to step up its effort to strengthen implementation capacity at all levels, including especially the mechanisms of financing flows and implementation modalities. For another, woreda-level authorities need to transmit signals to the federal government on the evolving situation in the woredas in crisis situations such as the current drought. Procedures need to be in place for monitoring the agreed roles and responsibilities so as to quickly detect policy/implementation failures and put in place remedial measures, thus improving accountability at all levels Assisting the Chronically Food Insecure. 27. As noted previously, calendar 2002 started with the need to care for an estimated 4.6 million people, in spite of the excellent harvest in most parts of the country. As has been the procedure to date, these needs were supplied under a relief program, and Government, U N agencies and donors continued to: (i) provide food aid to severely affected households, (ii) distribute seeds and other agricultural inputs, (iii) construct, rehabilitate and sink boreholes in drought affected areas through donor assisted schemes, and (iv) provide nutritional supplementary foods and health care services. In addition to these relief efforts, new programs were initiated designed to respond to the long term needs of these populations, and create new sustainable livelihoods, rebuild their asset base, and generate the ability to engage in sustainable livelihoods over the long term. The USAID funded Relief to Development program in selected woredas in Amhara region is one such effort. A World Bank funded Food Security Project (P050383, Credit 36460), targeting 12 drought prone food insecure woredas (in its first year) and 60 woredas at full development, has also been initiated. Under this project funding would be provided to communities in food insecure woredas in 4 highland regions to develop sustainable, diversified livelihoods; local Government would be strengthened and initiatives would be taken to improve food market efficiency, A Pastoral Communities Development Project (P 075915) is under preparation with support from the World Bank, which would focus poverty reduction in pastoral communities in lowland regions. In addition, most of the Birr 100 million allocation by the Federal Government in FY 2002 to support the Food Security Program is being used to provide a long term solution to drought related problems through investments in water harvesting structures, small scale irrigation works and other infrastructure. 7

It also provided Birr 13.11 million to affected Regions for the purchase of seeds to initiate replanting of early maturing crops. The project objective is to enable Government to help affectedfamilies survive the crisis, retain productive assets, and develop sustainable livelihoods, as well as contribute to stabilizing the macroeconomy. The project will: (i) defend critical human development expenditure by Government during the next year from the pressures caused by the current crisis; (ii) maintain the availability of critical economic inputs (particularly those needed in rural areas) and support the economic recovery process; (iii) rehabilitate and/or create communal assets using community labor of the affected population, and (iv) provide income supplements, and protect private assets of the affected population. The main indicator of project impact would be to reduce levels of outmigration of affected families from their homes. A logframe for the project is presented in Schedule F. Project Rationale 49. The current drought exacerbates the problems faced by vulnerable groups in the food insecure areas of Ethiopia, pushing an ever larger number of people to the brink. of survival. Vulnerability to the current drought has been increased, due to the cumulative effects of the asset depletion (i.e. the consumption of productive assets such as livestock, tools, health) incurred by families who survived the droughts of 1999 and 2000. The current project will endeavour to respond to the crisis through the strengthening of response mechanisms which defend minimum consurnption levels, and can continue to be developed and used as part of a standard safety net under a social protection program under the SDPRP. In designing the response, it is proposed to use the decentralized system of government and budget management which is being promulgated under the SDPRP, so that the machinery for response will become embedded in the new decentralized fiscal and service delivery structure of woreda Government. This project is seen as a complement to development initiatives already in place which seek to develop drought proofing infrastructure, in order to sustain the livelihoods of vulnerable groups in the food insecure woredas -- such as the Bank supported Food Security Project, the USAID supported Relief to Development project, the Pastoral Community Development Project which is under preparation with Bank support, the Poverty Reduction Strategy Credit, also under preparation with Bank support, and other initiatives. In keeping with this approach the emergency grant will help lay a foundation for a development oriented safety net which includes public works as a key component, although this project is not the main vehicle to construct such a system. It is recognized that the emergency grant needs to be fast disbursing and to conclude within a comparatively short time horizon. Public works and free distribution are not, however, the only feasible means to address both chronic and acute vulnerability. School enrolments generally fall during drought emergencies due to the need for child labor in foraging and other household activities as well as due to the fatigue of hunger. Yet, these merely reflect the fact that the drought exacerbates long term problems. Transfers that can be linked to protecting school attendance or to improved nutrition serve as human capital investments at the same time that they protect the vulnerable from the drought.  Financial Management Arrangements The Food Security Department (FSD) at the Ministry of Rural Development (MRD) will be responsible for the overall management of the project. The FSD is currently implementing a new IDA funded F'ood Security Project (Credit no. 3646-ET of USD 85 million as well as a government and EU funded Food Security Program. The Department has very little experience in implementing donor-financed projects. As a result of this, an experienced financial officer is required to design a simple financial management system that will produce accurate, reliable, timely and complete financial information about the project activities. The Woreda Finance Offices will handle all the transactions related to the project and will on regular basis report to the FSD at the MRD. Fund Flows The project will use a quick disbursing mechanism to disburse funds from the proceeds of the grant for the quick disbursing component where the government will submit expenditures incurred on positive list of imports agreed between the Government and the Bank. The quickc disbursing component will support critical imports through a positive list of import requirements linked to the drought and assist the government in drought recovery efforts. The Bank after reviewing evidences on the expenditures incurred on the positive lists of imports will transfer the foreign exchange in to the accounts of the MoFED to be opened at the National Bank of Ethiopia. One Special Account (SA) will be opened by the FSD at the National Bank of Ethiopia for the community grant and the project implementation and management components of the project. Funds from the proceeds of the grant will be transferred to this SA based on the four months estimated expenditures of the project. The initial advance will be USD 1.50 million, to be increased to 3.0 million once disbursements exceed SDR 3.5 million. Subsequent replenishments will be made on the basis of actual utilization. The project may use the Statement of Expenditures (SOEs) for al I community grants, training and operating costs; and consultancy services less than USD 100,000 for firms and less than USD 50,000 for individuals. Full documentation will be submitted for all contracts above the SOE limits. From the SA, the FSD may transfer money to the Woreda Finance Offices for eligible project expenditures. The Woreda Development Committee (WDC) assisted by the Worecla Rural Development Officer will approve specific proposals submitted by cornmunities. T'he Woreda Rural Development Officer will help communities to prepare proposals, activities to be performed by communities. Communities will enter into a contract with the WDC. Based on the aggregate proposals submitted by the WDC, the FSD will transfer money to the bank account of the Woreda Finance Office to be opened specifically for this purpose. The Woreda Finance Office based on the request from the WDC will transfer money to the communities in installments, 50% initially and the remaining 50% of the presentation satisfactory report on the utilization of the money. Communities are expected to provide supporting evidences for the utilization of the money and all the supporting documents will be kept at the Woreda Finance Office. Once the money is transferred to the communities, the Woreda Finance Office will prepare and send SOEs to the FSD. The FSD will consolidate all the SOEs collected from Woredas and the transactions at the FSD and submit withdrawal application to the Bank for the replenishment of the SA. Accounting and financial reportin' The FSD will be responsible to maintain records and accounts, which reflects the resources and expenditures of the project in line with sound accounting practice. The Finance Officer (FO) to be employed by the FSD will develop a simple project and financial management systems, which will provide adequate and relevant financial information on timely basis. The Financial transactions of the project will be recorded in accordance with acceptable accounting standards acceptable to the Bank. 29

 Schedule H Nutrition and Supplemental Feeding Ethiopia has the highest level of child malnutrition in Africa; the incidence of underweight children has been consistently around 45 percent over the last decade, much larger than the average incidence of 33 percent underweight children in Sub Saharan Africa in the nineties. Similarly, surveys in Ethiopia have persistently found more than half the children under five stunted, an indicator of chronic malnutrition. Stunting rates in these surveys often attaining more than 60 percent. By way of comparison the average prevalence of children stunted for 19 Sub Saharan African countries in the mid-nineties was 39 percenl.. The current drought clearly exacerbates this situation. Many woreda level assessments iindicate that rates of acute malnutrition are increasing, often exceeding 20% of the children, again far higher then the levels observed in previous welfare monitoring surveys. Malnutrition reflects a nexus of food access, health care, and child care. All three of these are affected by the drought; compounding the overall food shortage, child health is placed fit greater risk due to the shortage of water and the increase time burdens on care givers attendant to coping with the drought. GoE response includes the provision of a ration of supplementary food - imported corn-soy-blend (CSB) or locally produced mixes such as Famix and Unimix. Standard practice is to provide 15(0 gms per child per day or 4.5 kilos a month. Ideally this is to be targeted to children found to be malnourished in the course of screening or to pregnant and lactating women. The most pressing problem with this distribution is the shortage of appropriate formulas leading to breaks in distribution. Donations to the WFP have been insufficient to meet the expected distribution of between 10,000 and 16,000 tons a months, although the WFP reports increased pledges of CSB in recent weeks. In addition, while the DPPC plans to purchase up to 3,000 tons of Famnix (and has budgeted 1 8M birr) the factories that produce Famix and Unimix are working at capacity. Beyond the issue of aggregate availability, efficient distribution of supplementary foods requires a targeting mechanism. Not all woredas have conducted a nutritional survey and most that have done so still do not have the capacity for individual screening. It is also reported that households do not target this food on young children. This form of sharing within a household is commonly observed, albeit difficult to quantify. It is not clear why households that receive both 12.5 kilos of grain per capita as well as supplementary foods would share the supplementary food among the family while the grain supply remains available. It is more likely that this would happen if the household receives only supplementary foods (one woreda visited during assessment reported that the two categories of recipients do not necessarily overlap). It is also likely that a household would reduce the quantity of regular food provided to the child so that the supplementary food would not all be an addition to the total intake of the child. Yet, even in this case, the quality of the child's diet may still be more appropriate for growth than if the supplement were unavailable. However, international experience indicates that the provision of supplements alone is less likely to have a positive impact on child nutrition than if the distribution is accompanied by nutritional counseling that explains the proper preparation of the supplement, the age appropriate quantities and timing of meals, and other aspects of child care. Ideally, such counseling can also ensure that the child is up to date on inoculations and that he or she has received vitamin A and, where required, dewormning medicines. Few woredas have experience in such counseling, except where NGOs such as Concern and Save the Children have set up capacity. Even in many woredas where NGOs are active in food distribution the NGOs have not been able to establish a program for individual child screening and care giver counseling. Any improvements in local capacity for either of these activities would not only assist in drought response but also in establishing the base for investment in child nutrition. 39

 Schedule I Detailed Project Description Component 1: Community interventions Objective The community interventions component is to protect productive communal and private assets, prevent child malnutrition, and avert drought induced school dropouls. The component seeks to improve coping capabilities and protect productive assets of drought affected populations so as to enable them to recover their productive capacity following the emergency period. This would be accomplished by enhancing the effectiveness of existing food aid programs in drought affected areas, in rehabilitation or creation of community infrastructure, and provision of nutrition programs, or incentives to education. The project will work with ongoing Employment Generation Scheme and Gratuitous Relief programs managed by the Woreda government and supported by food aid. Rationale: The community interventions component attempts to mitigate three long tenn effects of the drought: increased vulnerability due to loss of economic productivity, adverse health impacts due to nutrition deficits and reduction of human capital caused by school dropouts. The productive capacities of communities are depleted by the drought in two ways: immediate reduction in crop or livestock production, which dramatically lowers current income, and reliance on coping mechanisms such as selling livestock or other assets, that render households less able to generate income in the future. As a result, vulnerability increases in the short and long term. Although the drought affected may receive survival assistance through income transfers such as food aid, the long term problem of asset depletion can lead to greater vulnerability. The growing number of chronically food insecure individuals (now estimated at 4 - 5 million) is an indication that more households experience long term vulnerability and are slipping into destitution. Malnutrition reflects a nexus across food access, health care, and child care, all three of which have been affected by the drought. In addition, child health is placed at greater risk due to the shortage of vvater and the increased time burdens on care givers attendant to coping with the drought. With the relatively high GAM rates found in drought affected areas, malnutrition represents a growing threat, especially among those highly vulnerable to nutrition deficits - the very young as well as pregnant or lactating women. Treating cases of very severe acute malnutrition requires costly therapeutic feeding, can result in devastating health impacts or death, and ultimately slows the recovery process. Preventing such an outcome can save resources as well as lives. Net primary school enrolments in rural areas of most regions in Ethiopia are in the range of 25-30 % and attendance often falls further during periods of drought due to demands for child labor as well as the effects of hunger. Girls enrolment is particularly vulnerable - the national ratio of girls to boys enrolment in primary and secondary school is only 61 %. School feeding is often proposed as a means to address drought related enrolment problems and is currently supported by WFP in some 600 schools. However, such programs incur high recurrent costs which the Ministry of Education views as unsustainable and, in light of the need for substantial investments in infrastructure, they may not be good candidates for counter-cyclical programs. A possible alternative to achieve many of the same objectives would be food (or cash) for education grants that are conditional on school attendance using similar mechanisms as are currently applied to the targeting of free food distribution. Construction or Rehabilitation of Communal Assets: The availability of cash for community interventions will allow drought affected communities to initiate and implement their own development agenda, target recovery efforts more effectively and allow greater success in completion and maintenance of selected assets. The Community asset building activities that 41
 are part of EGS are supported by government policy but ineffectively implemented due to lack of complementing cash or material resources. In practice, activities that are easiest to implement given resource, material, or technical expertise constraints have been the norm, and are primarily those that rely solely on community labor resources. Because projects become make-work activities rather than community investments or elements of Woreda development plans, many project activities are never completed nor maintained. Improving public workfare programs by providing cash to be used for purchase of materials, technical assistance or additional labor, would enable more effective and targeted rehabilitation activities - resulting in projects that more truly reflect community needs. Building on EGS (see Schedule G), the project would provide cash to complement, support and improve the development impact of the activities currently supported using payment (in food) for labour. The project will fund community based activities in 30-35 Woredas. Disbursement to affected communities would be against an accepted project proposal from the community. Specific community interventions will first take the form of a project proposal to be carried out by the community and will identify objectives, timing for implementation, resource requirements, community contributions and design parameters. Acceptance and implementation of the project proposal will be summarized in a simple contract signed between the community and Woreda Government, and will provide the basis for Bank disbursement against a community grant. Community grants amounts will be based on the number of affected households in the community.. Grants to communities will be allocated against a menu of public works and only include investments for community and Government owned or managed infrastructure. The project will also provide cash to finance additional materials needed to enable projects to address a broad range of community needs, provide supplemental labor payments or to contract in technical assistance. A comprehensive menu of public works will focus on: materials for reconstruction of roads, community schools and linked sanitation and water facilities, communal ponds, communal irrigation or water harvesting systems, or other infrastructure of common use. Woreda government will work with communities to complete the selected activity by: facilitating the community in identifying objectives, activities, timing for implementation, resource requirements, community contributions, and design parameters. In cases where Woreda Government lacks any of these functions, contracted organizations or individuals are to be used to complete implementation. Process indicators such as number of community grants and projects completed will be used to assess success, as will outcome indicators such as prevention of asset loss (sale of livestock, distressed migration). Targeted Nutrition The nutrition sub-component seeks to prevent malnutrition among small children and pregnant or lactating women in the drought affected population. Supplementary food provision should prevent further deterioration in health status of vulnerable populations and enable faster recovery from nutrition deficits. Malnutrition reflects a nexus of food access, health care, and child care, all three of which have been affected by the drought (see Schedule H). . In addition, child health is placed at greater risk due to the shortage of water and the increased time burdens on care givers attendant to coping with the drought. With the relatively high GAM rates found in drought affected areas, malnutrition represents a growing threat, especially among those highly vulnerable to nutrition deficits - the very young as well as pregnant or lactating women. Treating cases of very severe acute malnutrition requires costly therapeutic feeding, can result in devastating health impacts or death, and ultimately slows the recovery process. Preventing such an outcome can be save resources as well as lives. Government and donor response to prevent acute malnutrition includes the provision of a ration of supplementary food - impo. ed corn-soy-blend (CSB) or locally produced mixes such as Famix and 42
 Unimix. Standard practice is to provide 150 gins per child per day or 4.5 kilos a month tLrgeted to children found to be malnourished in the course of screening. Although it is likely that households reduce the quantity of regular food provided to the child so that the supplementary food would not all be an addition to the total intake of the child, the quality of the child's diet may still be more appropriate for growth than if the supplement were unavailable. The most pressing problem with supplementary food provision among the drought affected is the shortage of appropriate formulas. Donations to the WFP have been insufficient to meet the expected distribution of between 10,000 and 16,000 tons a month and DPCC lacks resource to purchase large amounts locally. Provision of supplementary food to Woredas receiving the cash grant sub-component of the EDRP would fill a critical gap in drought recovery efforts and maintain nutritional stattus in the most vulnerable populations. The sub-component will complement food aid distribution associated with the Gratuitous Relief program and finance the inclusion of supplementary enriched food targeted at small children and pregnant and lactating women. It will permit funding to claose the gap between the donations received and the requireemtns to provide an additional 4.5 kg/per month of supplementary food (Famix, Unimix, or CSB) will be allocated to each eligible individual receiving food aid through DPCC or donor agencies. Distribution to affected populations will be organized by DPPC, who will receive the allocation of supplementary food at the federal level and distribute along with normal food aid deliveries. However, international experience indicates that the provision of supplements alone is less likely to have a positive impact on child nutrition than if the distribution is accompanied by nutritional education regarding the proper preparation of the supplement, the age appropriate quantities and timing of meals, and other aspects of child care. The project will fund mass media or other nutritional education programs to complement the provision of the supplementary food. Nutritional data gathered through DPPC and other surveys will be the primary indicator used. School Attendance Promotion The school attendance program is aimed at maintaining school enrolment in drought afficted through provision of cash or food transfers to drought affected families in return for school attendance by girl children. Net primary school enrolments in rural areas of most regions in Ethiopia are in the range, of 25-30 % and attendance often falls further during periods of drought due to demands for child labor as well as the effects of hunger. Girls enrolment is particularly vulnerable - the national ratio of girls to boys enrolment in primary and secondary school is only 61 %. School feeding is often proposed as a means to address drought related enrolment problems and is currently supported by WFP in some 600 schools. However, such programs incur high recurrent costs which the Ministry of Education views as unsustainable and, in light of the need for substantial investments in infrastructure, they may not be good candidates for counter-cyclical programs. A possible alternative to achieve many of the same objectives would be food (or cash) for education grants that are conditional on school attendance using similar mechanisms as are currently applied to the targeting of free food distribution. Human resource assets represent the long term future of rural development in Ethiopia and efforts to encourage school attendance have received little attention in much of Ethiopia's food security efforts. Although one significant contributor to school drop out - internal migration - is not likely to be affected by school based programs, successful general relief efforts should mitigate this factor. School grants for enrolment represent an effective medium term response to the impact of drought on eduicational attainment. 43
 The WFP manages a pilot project in pastoral areas that provides four liters of cooking oil every two months to girls who attend at least 80% of school days in a given period as certified by a teacher. The project will fund an extension of this project to schools in Somali and Afar regions regardless of whether the schools currently have a school meal program. WFP will serve as advisors to the GoE and thus create capacity in the administration and procurement issues necessary for such a project. Component 2: Ouick disbursing assistance Objective: The quick disbursing component will finance key economic inputs through a positive list of imports. Such financing will enable Government to respond to the drought emergency by providing foreign exchange and counterpart revenue for use in the Government's drought recovery efforts. This will also prevent re-direction of public investment away from the long term poverty reduction program. Rationale: Ethiopia's recent macroeconomic gains are threatened by the drought, which will not only increase public expenditures, but lower economic growth. As noted above, the Government's revised macroeconomic forecast anticipates large increases in government expenditures and a worsening trade deficit. According to the IMF, Ethiopia has only recently doubled its international reserves from 2 to 4 months of imports and importation of drought relief and recovery materials - food, fertilizer, seeds, medicines and transportation equipment - will require scarce foreign exchange. Much of the international response to the emergency is in the form of food aid with relatively little allocated to non-food assistance. This component will allow Government to maintain a supply of critical economic inputs for recovery efforts by providing finance for imports. The 2002/2003 drought has also put greater stress on the Government's Development Budget by increasing public expenditure requirements. Social spending in Ethiopia has risen consistently in past years and accounted for 22.6 percent of all total government expenditures in 2001. This was a substantial increase over previous years and reflected the Government's renewed commitment to poverty reduction. However, the human development and poverty reduction agenda may be jeopardized by drought relief requirements as it was during the emergency caused by war with Eritrea - when social expenditures dropped from a high of 24 percent of total expenditures in 1996/1997 to 16 percent in 1999/2000. (IMF, 2002) Defending human development expenditures will be key to maintaining the human resource asset base necessary for Ethiopia's long term development. Description: The quick disbursing component will finance a positive list of imports (Schedule A) that includes a list of items essential to support the recovery of the economy, and of the agriculture sector in particular. The imports financed on Government's account and the counterpart generated from private sector imports will be used to support the national Emergency Drought Recovery Program. Retroactive financing of up to 20 percent of the total will be allowed for purchases posted after December 7th 2002. Key performance indicators: The outcomes envisaged by the component - defense of Government's social expenditures and stable supply of critical inputs - will be measured by price data and sectoral shares of government budget allocations. Component 3: Project Manacement The project coordination, monitoring and study component will support implementation of components 1 and 2 with the additional objective of contributing to the policy dialogue that surrounds food security and safety net programs in Ethiopia. Program monitoring and funded technical studies should develop greater understanding of food security and vulnerability issues as well as the role of a medium term response to drought crises. 44
 The Government's Food Security Program is at the center of efforts to link development and relief activities with EGS as its primary instrument. International best practice in public workfare schemes show large differences with Ethiopia's EGS version, primarily in targeting criteria, selection of activities, implementation arrangements, participation norms, and wage rates. Further study on public workfare programs in the Ethiopian context could inform Government and donor activities in this area. Other aspects of vulnerability reduction - community targeting, nutrition, school attendance - are also important to broadening the policy debate and contributing to the greater success of current and future drought recovery projects. The emergency nature of the project necessitates quick implementation and administration of the project. Technical support is particularly necessary, as the community project activities envisioned in the community intervention sub-component will likely require expertise not available at the Kebele or Woreda level. Design of irrigation systems, water harvesting structures, and road or building construction may be required and exceed local capacity. Funding support will be provided to staff and administer the project managenment unit, training of Woreda government in project implementation, technical expertise for community project activities, creation of amonitoring and evaluation system, and studies on food security and vulnerability reduction. 45

doc.abstracts: The Emergency Drought Recovery Project in Ethiopia, will enable the Government to help affected families survive the emergency, retain productive assets, and develop sustainable livelihoods, and in addition, will contribute to stabilizing the macro-economy. Main project outcomes will contribute to defend critical human development expenditure by the Government during the first year of the crisis; maintain the availability of critical economic inputs (particularly in rural areas), and support the economic recovery process; rehabilitate and create communal assets, using community labor within affected populations; and, provide income supplements, and protect private assets of affected populations. The main indicator of project impact would be reduced levels of out-migration of affected families from their homes. While the project will undoubtedly assist drought-affected populations through cash inputs, and macroeconomic stabilization, risks include weak management capacity, particularly at the community levels, which as stipulated, the use of existing, simple systems will be used to reach communities, and improve program impacts. Moreover, taking into consideration that the dependence on food aid among rural communities in food insecure areas, may be deepened, project aid in the provision of income, and infrastructure development, should support regeneration of productive assets.
